name: Dichloro(difluoro)methane
Reason: 1,1,1,2,2-pentafluoroethane has a melting point of -172.0 degrees Celsius. Chlorine substituents significantly increase the melting point due to strong electronegativity which leads to stronger intermolecular dipole-dipole interactions. Each chlorine is estimated to increase the melting point by approximately 10 degrees Celsius, giving a total increase of (10 degrees Celsius x 2 chlorines) = 20 degrees Celsius. Additionally, the difluoro group can also contribute to the melting point due to increased molecular weight and potential hydrogen bonding, estimated at around +5 degrees Celsius.
